question.content: The rebels laid up their arms

solution.content: (a) Laid down  The  phrase  “laid  down”  means  surrendering  or  putting  something  down.  Hence,  ‘Laid  down’  is  the  most  appropriate  answer.

question.content: She has gained a lot of fame but still she is very realistic and sensible.

solution.content: a) down to earth-  very realistic and sensible.  down to it-  focused on the task at hand.  down to bottom-  at the lowest point.  down to drown-  to sink under water and die

question.content: He was advised for walking alone in the neighbourhood.

solution.content: Advised against  The  verb  ‘advise’  is  often  followed  by  the  preposition  ‘against’  when  giving  a  warning  to  avoid  something.  Hence,  ‘advised  against’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The volunteers of the organisation refused point blank of do what was requested.

options.text: refused in point blank of doing

solution.content: refused point blank to do  ‘Of’  must  be  replaced  with  ‘to’  as  ‘refused  point  blank’  is  an  idiom  and  it  should  be  followed  by  ‘to  +  infinitive(V  1  ).’  Hence,  ‘refused  point blank to do’ is the most appropriate answer

question.content: Students were asked to write the historical events in the order of their occurrence .

solution.content: chronological  order-  in  the  order  of  their  occurrence.  Aesthetic  order  -  organize  things  in  a  way  that  emphasizes  their  beauty.  Historic  order  -  arranging  things  based  on  their  historical  importance or relevance.  Diachronic  order  -  organizing  things  based  on  their  evolution  or  changes over time

question.content: Reading has the capacity to make a man wise , but reading of only textbooks is like living in room of our same height. Pinnacle Sentence Improvement

options.text: Reading shall make a man wise
Reading should make a man wise

solution.content: Reading makes a man wise ‘Simple  present  tense(Singular.Sub  +  V  1  -s/es  +  obj  )’  will  be  used  in  the  given  sentence  as  it  is  used  to  describe  a  fact  or  universal  truth.  Hence,  ‘reading  makes  a  man  wise’  is  the  most  appropriate  answer

question.content: A lot of people are seen gathering, discussing and negotiating in front of our stall in the town.

solution.content: Bargaining  ‘Bargain’ means to discuss and negotiate. Hence, ‘Bargaining’ is  the most appropriate answer

question.content: The captain disdained the roaring impatience and mutinous disposition of his crews.

solution.content: Treated with scorn  ‘Disdained’  means  to  be  Treated  with  scorn  or  unworthy  of  one's  consideration.  Hence,  ‘treated  with  scorn’  is  the  most  appropriate answer.

question.content: The walls of the temple caved out due to weak construction.

solution.content: In  The  phrase  “Cave  in”  means  to  collapse;  subside.  Hence,  ‘cave  in’  is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The heading of the newspaper shout at the readers to stay inside their homes.

solution.content: Shouted at the readers  We  need  to  use  simple  past  tense(V  2  )  to  make  the  sentence  grammatically  correct.  Hence,  ‘Shouted(V  2  )  at  the  readers’  is  the  most appropriate answer.

question.content: Extreme sadness and pitiful cries of people filled the whole atmosphere.

solution.content: The heart rending cries  ‘Heart  Rending’  means  something  that  causes  you  to  feel  great  sadness  and  pity.  Hence,  ‘the  heart  rending  cries’  is  the  most  appropriate answer.

question.content: Dheerubai, a source of inspiration to the present generation, started life very poor and then later in life became very rich.

solution.content: Went  from  rags  to  riches-  to  start  your  life  very  poor  and then later in life become very rich

question.content: The report claimed that a consensus was growing against the absolute authority in the country.

solution.content: Generally accepted agreement  In the Sentence ‘Consensus’ means generally accepted  agreement. Hence, ‘Generally accepted agreement’ is the most  appropriate answer

question.content: India went forward all odds and won the match against West Indies.

solution.content: against  ‘Forward’ must be replaced with ‘against’ as the phrase ‘go  against’  means  to  oppose  or  resist  something.  Hence,  ‘against’  is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Last summer I went to my village, the place of my birth, to spend a short holiday.

solution.content: Native village  ‘Native’  means  associated  with  the  place  of  a  person's  birth.  Hence, ‘native village’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: There are numerous anecdotes about famous personalities that exist in various parts of the world.

options.text: Short accounts of real and interesting incidents
Stories that express ideas through symbols
Statements accepted as true without proof

answer: Short accounts of real and interesting incidents

solution.content: Anecdotes  -  Short  accounts  of  real  and  interesting  incidents.

question.content: Anyone reading these lines will thought that the writer is very sad.

options.text: will have think that the writer is
have thinking that the writer is
are think that the writer has
will think that the writer is

answer: will think that the writer is

solution.content: will think that the writer is  ‘Thought’  must  be  replaced  with  ‘think’  as  we  generally  use  V  1  with  the  helping  verb  will.  Hence,  ‘will  think  that  the  writer  is’  is  the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He brought these sweets for you and I .

solution.content: For you and me  Replace  ‘I’  with  ‘me’  in  the  sentence.  Because  we  never  use  subjective  cases  in  objective  places.  Hence,  ‘he  brought  these  sweets for you and me’ is the most appropriate answer

question.content: The money arrived when I (little) expected it.

options.text: The money arrived when I expected it.
The money arrived when I least expected it.
The money arrived when I less expected it.
The money arrived when I little expected it.

answer: The money arrived when I least expected it.

solution.content: The money arrived when I least expected it. (  Correct  )  The three degrees of comparison for less (less, lesser, least)

question.content: In the introductory session, the teacher asked me to what district I came from.

solution.content: Which district  In  the  given  sentence  ‘which’  used  as  a  function  word  to  introduce  a  relative  clause  that  modifies  a  noun  ‘the  introductory  session’. Hence, which distinct is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I asked two people the way to Diana’s house but no one of them knew it .

options.text: whether either of them knew it
if none of them knew it
that no one of them knew it
but neither of them knew it

answer: but neither of them knew it

solution.content: but neither of them knew it  ‘No  one’  must  be  replaced  with  ‘neither’  as  we  generally  use  ‘no  one’  to  denote  more  than  two  subjects  ‘neither’  to  denote  two  subjects.  Hence,  ‘but  neither  of  them  knew  it’  is  the  most  appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the correct superlative degree of comparison for the given sentence. This is one of the beautiful places in the area.

options.text: This is one of the most beautiful places in the area.
This is one of the more beautiful places in the area.
This is one of the beautiful places in the area.
This is a beautiful place in the area.

answer: This is one of the most beautiful places in the area.

solution.content: This is one of the most beautiful places in the area.  The  superlative  degree  of  the  adjective  beautiful  is  ‘most  beautiful’. Hence, option (a) is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the correct superlative degree of comparison for the given sentence. I told him my inner feelings.

options.text: I told him my innermost feelings.
I told him my in feelings
I told him my more inner feelings.

answer: I told him my innermost feelings.

solution.content: I told him my innermost feelings.  In  the  given  sentence  the  correct  superlative  degree  of  comparison  is  ‘Innermost  feelings’.  Hence,  ‘I  told  him  my  innermost feelings’ is the most appropriate sentence.

question.content: Select the correct degree of comparison for the given sentence. David looks ( old ) than he really is.

options.text: David looks old than he really is.
David looks older than he really is.
David looks elder than he really is.
David looks elder from he really is.

answer: David looks older than he really is.

solution.content: David looks older than he really is  The  correct  comparative  degree  of  the  adjective  ‘old’  is  ‘older’.  Hence, option (a) is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The numbers applying for the course had dropped off very sharply during the pandemic.Pinnacle Sentence Improvement

solution.content: have dropped off sharply  We  generally  use  ‘present  perfect  tense(have  +  V  3  )  to  represent  an  action  that  just  happened  in  the  recent  past  and  still  has  its  effect.  Hence,  ‘have  dropped  off  sharply’  is  the  most  appropriate  answer.
